data.title: Supporting Kevin Nolan aus Irland
data.meta_description: Singer-Songwriter, Philosoph, Multiinstrumentalist und Autor verÃ¶ffentlicht sein DebÃ¼t Fredrick & The Golden Dawn.
data.text:
Es ist kein Geheimnis, dass die grÃ¼ne Insel wahrhaft gute KÃ¼nstler_innen hervorbringt. Einer davon ist der sehr hÃ¶fliche und zuvorkommende Multiinstrumentalist Kevin Nolan, der es gleichwohl versteht, Poetisches zu erschaffen und diese Poesie dann u.a. in seine Musik einflieÃen zu lassen. Er selbst sieht sein DebÃ¼talbum âFredrick & The Golden Dawnâ als Mix aus Tom Waits und Stereolab. Er liebt deutsche KÃ¼nstler_innen wie Ute Lemper, Dagmar Krause, Hanns Eisler, Bertolt Brecht, EinstÃ¼ârzende Neubautenâ, âKurt Weil und Lotte Lenya. Eine interessante und gleichzeitig bizarre Mischung, wie ich finde. Lernt ihn hier ein bisschen besser kennen.

***

Das Interview erfolgte per Mail.

Please introduce yourself to the readers.

Good evening readers, my name is Kevin Nolan. I was born in Dublin City, Ireland. Iâm a singer/composer and I write poetry. Iâve just released my debut album entitled âFredrick & The Golden Dawnâ with the Eire Supply label. My second book of poetry which was co-written with artist Susanne Wawra is entitled âSchizo-Poetry â Fragments Of Mindâ and will be published in early 2015.

Would you say that you are a professional musician or is it more a hobby?

Neither, itâs not a hobby as I do it nine to five everyday of my life and Iâm not professional as Iâm not signed to a big label. Iâm in a kind of hallowed chrysalis state waiting for the curtains to rise and drama to commence.

How would you describe your music?

My old friend and author Rob Doyle once wrote âNolan is a seething cauldron full of the literary, the theatrical, and the gothically flamboyant, seasoned with a smattering of infernal burlesque.â He really understood my album. As for my own opinion, my album is a collection of wonder-tales. It sort of fills the mould of an extreme sensibility. Itâs in a way a bad reaction to something I ate, I mean emotionally. Itâs a refusal to accept the place in which I found myself, a kind of revolt. This album is for those who want to reach outside somehow. Itâs a mix of Stereolab, Tom Waits, Captain Beefheart, Steve Reich, Nick Cave, Scott Walker, Bertolt Brecht and Leonard Cohen among others. These are all wrapped up and digested by own my imagination. Then mixed with my sensibilities and regurgitated as a work which had an eight year gestation period.

How did it comeÂ that you are so much into German music?

I remember my mother playing Marlene Dietrich when I was a child. Who knows? Maybe my love of German music began there. In my formative years I had a romantic connection with Germany as an open-minded art filled place. I remember hearing about David Bowie and Iggy Pop’s Berlin years and of how Bowie in particular loved German music and even covered âThe Alabama Songâ as did Jim Morrison and many others. I became aware of Weil and Lenya and loved what I heard. I got more and more into German music. Then a good friend showed me an album called âTank Battles: The Songs of Hanns Eislerâ. I thought these were magical songs and so close to my own musical leanings. I became fanatical about Dagmar Krause, which lead me to the Art Bears and others. I remember going to see Ute Lemper in The National Concert Hall in Dublin City many years ago. She sang many Brecht songs and slowly I just fell in love with this whole German scene. This was the musical language I was looking for as a form for my own expression, these were the songs and the voices.

I read that your music is influenced byÂ Hanns Eisler, Lotte Lenya or Ute Lemper. ItÂ´s a very special kind of music – What fascinates you?

In the songs of say Krause, Dietrich, Lenya, Eisler and others there is a particular type of delivery of the lyric which is uniquely German and itâs intoxicating in its dynamic. The emotion expressed is so vital and immediate and the orchestration is also very unique. There is a sense of something real being expressed, something true, something intensely true. The truth is in the performance; itâs in the music and in the voice and the intonation. The music is full of heartache so genuinely and gutturally expressed.Â This is something I always wanted to emulate in my own music.

Do you understand the Lyrics?

I donât speak German, so the only way I ever become aware of the meaning of the lyrics is when I read translations or if I hear a cover version in English. So in a way I have a strange relationship to these songs which leaves much room for imagination. For me this is a real strength as I believe that sometimes in art, a misinterpretation can be more valuable than an correct interpretation. For the reason that, when you hear something that you donât fully understand, it leaves a beautiful space for which to inject your own personal sensibilities. The misreading is completely your own, and this misunderstanding I find is great food for creating my own music.

Are there any upcoming gigs?

Yes, in January Iâm playing The First Fortnight Festival in Dublin City and also lined up for the new year are shows with two artists I really admire. The Revelator Orchestra and Thomas Truax. So Iâm looking forward to them.

Do you come to Germany soon?

Iâm hoping to come to Berlin and Weimar in late spring.

What are your plans for the future?

My second book will be published in early 2015 and Iâm going to tour my debut album for a year or so. Then Iâll go back into the studio for album number two, and so it goes.
